conclusion: Analyzing a complete cycle of the ideal gas on a P-V diagram.
Process b→c is an isochoric heating (vertical line upward at constant volume).
Process c→d is an adiabatic expansion (curved line decreasing from c to d).
Process d→a is an isochoric cooling (vertical line downward at constant volume).
Process a→b is an adiabatic compression (curved line increasing from a to b).
During process b→c, heat is absorbed by the system.
During process c→d, there is no heat transfer (Q = 0).
During process d→a, heat is released by the system.
During process a→b, there is no heat transfer (Q = 0).
Heat is absorbed only during process b→c and released only during process d→a.
The temperature change from d→a is smaller than from b→c.
For an ideal gas in an isochoric process, |Q_absorbed| > |Q_released|.
In a complete cycle, the amount of heat absorbed is greater than the amount of heat released.
